column1: Sequels: none I’ve never left a trail behind me. [SEP] Never. [SEP] There’s no notes, no writing on the wall, no physical signs of affliction. [SEP] At least, nothing unusual. [SEP] The most complex machine in the universe just... falls apart, if one can mess it up just right. [SEP] It’s a delicate process. [SEP] Most usually just
column3: to pieces & do my job for me. [SEP] Some are tougher than others. [SEP] That’s where force comes in. [SEP] I have my methods. [SEP] It’s usually my trusty switchblade. [SEP] Out comes the switchblade. [SEP] A few small scrapes on the back of the hand, or the shoulder, or on the heel. [SEP] Whatever’s handy. column1: “We, and thousands like us, have been living separately as long as there has been a human society,” said my driver. [SEP] I noticed that the wrinkles on his neck expanded as he breathed and realized that they were gills. [SEP] “We interact with humans, take advantage of them, grant them boons, sometimes even become their friends, but the majority of both societies have little or no interaction. At this point, we have removed ourselves so fully from quotidian human existence that we are understood to be fictional. “The only place with any significant interaction between our worlds is on the fringes of yours. Love-ins, raves, gatherings where society is put on hold and humans open themselves to emotion: that is where entities from this world tend to
column3: when they cross over, and that is where Rachel met someone from this world. Those of us who live permanently in this world tend to set up in places like this, where the human population is so overwhelming that they won’t be noticed in the right corner, with the right protective spells.” [SEP] He took out the hunchback’s directions and glanced at an alley behind us. [SEP] “Okay, Nathan. We should get started right away. There’s no time to waste.”

column1: Some new information has come to light over the Kursk disaster. [SEP] (For those with short attention spans, the Kursk was the submarine that blew up and sank in the Arctic Ocean killing all 118 on board.) [SEP] The Russians tried to blame the incident on a collision with an unidentified object. [SEP] However, sonar tapes which recorded the blasts (a small one at first, then a much larger one, two minutes later), cast doubt on these claims. [SEP] A whistle-blower within the Russian military has leaked that the crew of the Kursk was testing a new type of torpedo when the accident occurred. [SEP] It seemed very likely that the test didn't
column3: quite as planned. [SEP] While rescue efforts to save the survivors of the Kursk failed, salvage crews were able to recover a 'Black Box' from the submarine which recorded events leading up to the explosion. [SEP] As luck would have it, we managed to obtain a copy of those tapes. [SEP] It turns out that the submarine crew was trying to load Microsoft Windows on their fire control computer. [SEP] Their intent was to replace the aging CP/M operating system with the flashier Windows OS. [SEP] Apparently, the Russians didn't know about the legendary stability problems exhibited by Windows. [SEP] The log tapes make this painfully obvious:

column1: EP] Today, Hewlett’s and Terman’s philosophy permeates the region. [SEP] Despite fierce inter-firm competition, open information exchange is common practice among the region’s producers. [SEP] Several features of the Valley contribute to creating a ‘weak’ environment. [SEP] The high pace of technology and product life cycles, fluidity of firm formation and failure, rapid employee turnover resulting in little com-pany-specific socialisation, as well as a lack of meaningful institutionally based hierarchy, all contribute to an environment in which individuals rely on alternative cues to guide their behaviour. [SEP] For example, in the Valley, technology moves quickly and competition is tough. [SEP] New firms form almost overnight -and many disappear just as quickly. [SEP] When firms come and
column3: like ships in the night it is not surprising that employees tend to identify with their profession, not their company. [SEP] Moreover, people’s loyalty is not only to their profession, but to the host industry region. [SEP] ‘As one local semiconductor executive reportedly noted: ‘‘Many of us wake up in the morning thinking that we work for Silicon Valley Inc.’’ ’ (Saxenian, 1996, p. 23). [SEP] They view job-changing as the norm. [SEP] Average job tenure is in the area of two years, and annual turnover is around 35%, and often higher for smaller firms (Saxenian, 1996). [SEP] As one engineer explained: ‘two or three years is about the max [at a job] for the Valley because there’s always something more interesting across the street’ (Saxenian, p. 28).
